Locating the active sites of metallocene catalysts supported on acid-treated montmorillonite Takao Tayano ⁎ Hideshi Uchino Takehiro Sagae Shigeki Ohta Shinichi Kitade Hideshi Satake Masahide Murata Research and Development Division, Japan Polychem Corporation, 1, Toho-cho Yokkaichi, Mie 510-0848, Japan Research and Development Division Japan Polychem Corporation 1 Toho-cho Yokkaichi Mie 510-0848 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this study, we investigated the location of the active sites of montmorillonite-supported metallocene catalysts used for propylene polymerization. X-ray fluorescence, Hammett titration, and scanning transmission electron microscopy/energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy revealed that the gradual leaching of Al atoms from the borders of the platelets to their centers and acid site formation occurred when montmorillonite was subjected to an acid treatment. X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy analyses indicated that the metallocene complex was activated only on the borders of the acid-treated montmorillonite platelets. The most plausible explanation for this phenomenon is that the metallocene complex is activated by the acid sites formed on the borders of the platelets by the acid treatment of montmorillonite. Keywords Metallocene catalyst Montmorillonite Activator Support Active site 1 Introduction Metallocene catalysts have been studied widely for use in olefin polymerization since Kaminsky et al. reported that methylaluminoxane (MAO) is an effective cocatalyst for metallocene activation [1]. In particular, significant efforts have been devoted to developing more effective cocatalysts. To this end, MAO [2] has been modified, and various boron compounds such boranes and borates [3] have been developed. Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation (MCC) has developed unique clay minerals that can act as specific support materials for activating metallocenes in the absence of additional compounds [4,5]. With respect to the activation mechanism, MAO is a difficult compound to study, given that it exhibits multiple and complex structures [6–9]. The activation performance of a material depends strongly on the synthesis procedure used and on its storage conditions. Therefore, being able to identify which chemical species in a MAO mixture is capable of activation is essential. Coevoet et al. investigated the reaction of zirconocene dichloride with MAO using ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy and found that the reaction mode depended on the ratio of MAO and the complex [10]. In the case of an Al/Zr ratio lower than 30, only a monomethyl complex was obtained. For all other cases, the monomethyl complex was converted into a cationic species of zirconocene monomethyl. Wieser et al. studied the acidity of various MAO species [11]. They found that two types of MAO species exhibit different acidities. MAOA is a stronger Lewis acid than is MAOB and is capable of releasing cation species more readily. In the cases where MAO is used in a high enough amount, the proportion of MAOA becomes higher. In case of clay minerals, three active species have been proposed to explain metallocene activation: MAO [12], anchored aluminum compounds [13–15], and the acid sites of the clay minerals [16]. Novokshonova et al. reported that MAO prepared on clay minerals shows the same fragmentation profiles during temperature-programmed desorption mass spectrometry as does dry MAO and that it acts as a cocatalyst in the system [12]. Because their research objective was to develop immobilized MAO compounds, they intentionally used clay minerals that contained water of constitution for the partial hydrolysis of alkylaluminum compounds such as trimethylaluminum (TMA). On the other hand, Jeong et al. reported that the products formed during the partial hydrolysis of TMA with acidic montmorillonite (MMT) are capable of activating metallocenes for ethylene polymerization; this was the case even though the MMT was dehydrated before being placed in contact with TMA [13]. They concluded that dehydrated MMT contains only reactive OH groups and an insignificant amount of water for forming MAO. In addition, because the surface species formed by the reaction of the OH group and TMA did not exhibit any activity, they did not consider MAO to be an active species. The first generation of MCC clay mineral technology was a hydrolysis technique similar to Novokshonova’s method [4]. However, MCC changed their strategy from a wet system-based one to a dry system-based one [5], owing to the difficulty in achieving further improvements. In the latter case, Takahashi et al. reported the acid sites of a clay-mineral-activated metallocene dialkyl when used for ethylene polymerization in the absence of organoaluminum compounds [16]. Their findings were supported by those of Sano’s study on the aluminated siliceous material AlMCM-41 [17]. The Lewis acid sites on AlMCM-41 caused the activation of the metallocene when it was used for propylene polymerization in the absence of organoaluminum compounds. While there is some debate regarding the active species in the clay mineral catalyst system, we believe that an acidic system is necessary in all cases. In addition, the location of the active sites in the clay mineral system remains the subject of discussion. Because clay minerals typically have a layered structure, the doping of chemicals into the gap between adjacent layers (i.e., intercalation) is a common technique for tailoring their properties. Therefore, a few researchers believe that the active sites are formed in the interlayer region. Kurokawa et al. reported that ethylene is polymerized by intercalated active metallocene molecules after the peeling of the individual layers of the metallocene catalyst system when it is supported on Mg2+-treated mica [18]. On the other hand, the acid treatment of natural clay minerals in water is essential for metallocene activation [19]. Thus, it is highly probable that the active sites are located on the surfaces of the clay mineral particles, which are primarily modified by the acid treatment [20]. It is, therefore, critical to correctly identify the location of the active sites in order to elucidate the catalyst system and to improve its performance, as the two proposed locations mentioned above are completely different. With this goal in mind, we performed analytical studies to determine the location of the active sites; this was done by investigating the chemical and structural changes induced in the clay minerals after the chemical treatment and the polymerization process. We selected a propylene polymerization catalyst consisting of chemically treated MMT and a specific complex developed by Japan Polychem Corporation as a typical example [21]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Kunipia F (KF) (a commercial product purchased from Kunimine Industry Co., Ltd.) was used as the raw material for MMT. rac-Dimethylsilylene bis[1,1-{2-methyl-4-(4-chlorophenyl)-4-hydroazulenyl}]zirconium dichloride (Azu-Zr) was prepared according to the procedure listed in its patent application and used as the metallocene complex for the catalyst for propylene polymerization [21]. The structure of the Azu-Zr metallocene and the assignments of its 1H NMR chemical shifts are shown in Fig. 1 .We wish Fig.1 is reduced half current size(single column width). Industrial grade heptane and toluene were purified using molecular sieves (4A) and were subjected to dry nitrogen bubbling before use. Triisobutylaluminum (TiBA) diluted in heptane as solvent (Tosoh Finechem Corporation) was used as purchased without further purification. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4), anthraquinone, 2-benzalacetophenone, and 2,6-dimethylpyridine (purchased from Wako Pure Chemicals Industry Ltd.) were also used as purchased without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Sulfuric acid treatment of Kunipia F A 2L separable four-necked flask, to which a mechanical agitation unit, a water condenser, and a thermometer were connected, was used for the treatment. Distilled water (850mL) and concentrated H2SO4 (250g) were added to the flask and heated to 90°C using an oil bath. Kunipia F (150g) was added to the acid solution to start the treatment. The concentration of H2SO4 in the reaction mixture was 20wt%. After 2h, the solid formed was collected by filtration and repeatedly washed with cold distilled water until the pH of the slurry was not lower than 4. The obtained cake of the clay mineral was dried in an oven at 120°C overnight. The agglomerated portion of the dried powder was removed, and the remaining powder was dried under vacuum at 200°C for 2h; this sample was labeled as KF(1). KF(2) and KF(3) were prepared in a similar manner; the only difference was that the reaction times were 5 and 8h, respectively. 2.2.2 TiBA treatment of acid-treated MMT All the operations were performed in dry N2 using standard Schlenk techniques. Into a three-necked flask (1L) equipped with a mechanical agitation unit, 20g of KF(2) and 73mL of dry heptane were introduced. To the resulting dispersion, a heptane solution of TiBA (50mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred at 25°C for 1h. The supernatant liquid was removed by decantation, and the solid material was washed twice with 900mL of heptane. Then, the solid material was dried by vacuum evaporation at 40°C. The obtained sample, labeled as KF(4), was stored in a dry N2 atmosphere. 2.2.3 Synthesis of supported metallocene catalyst All the operations were performed in a dry N2 atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. Into a three-necked flask (100mL) equipped with a stirrer, 0.7g of KF(2) and 5mL of heptane were introduced. Then, the heptane solution of TiBA (1.66mmol) was added to the flask, and the mixture was stirred at 25°C for 1h. The supernatant liquid was removed by decantation, and the solid material was washed twice with 90mL of heptane. Next, the heptane solution of TiBA (112μmol) and a heptane solution of Azu-Zr (28μmol) were introduced. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1h. After the supernatant liquid had been removed by decantation, the solid material was washed twice with 90mL of heptane. Then, the solid material was dried by vacuum evaporation at 40°C. This yielded the supported metallocene catalyst (KF(5)). 2.2.4 Synthesis of catalyst sample containing tiny amount of polypropylene All the operations were performed in a dry N2 atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. In a three-necked flask (1L) equipped with a mechanical agitation unit, 12g of KF(2) was suspended in 160mL of heptane. Then, the heptane solution of TiBA (30mmol) was added to the suspension at room temperature and agitated for 1h. The supernatant liquid was removed by decantation, and the solid material was washed twice with 900mL of heptane. Next, the heptane solution of TiBA (1.44mmol) and a toluene solution of Azu-Zr (360μmol) were successively introduced into the flask and made to react for 0.5h at room temperature. The liquid phase of the suspension was removed, and the solid was washed with dry toluene twice. The dried supported metallocene catalyst was obtained by vacuum evaporation of the solvent at 40°C. A catalyst sample containing a tiny amount of polypropylene was prepared by short-time gas-phase polymerization. Into a 500mL three-necked flask to which a mechanical agitation unit and a three-way cock were connected, the supported metallocene catalyst described above was introduced and stirred gently at 0°C. A rubber balloon filled with a mixture of propylene and N2 (total gas volume of 2.55L and propylene/N2 volume ratio of approximately 0.3) was connected to the three-way cock. The gas mixture was introduced into the flask through the cock, and the gas phase was immediately replaced by N2, resulting in the quenching of the polymerization process after a very short reaction time (within several seconds) and the minimization of the polymer content in the solid. The obtained solid was used without further treatment. In this manner, a catalyst sample containing a tiny amount polypropylene (KF(6)) was obtained. 2.2.5 Synthesis of prepolymerized catalyst All the operations were performed in dry N2 using standard Schlenk techniques. To a three-necked flask (1L) equipped with a mechanical agitation unit, 20g of KF(2) was suspended in 129mL of heptane. Then, the heptane solution of TiBA (50mmol) was added to the suspension at room temperature and agitated for 1h. The supernatant liquid was removed by decantation, and the solid material was washed twice with 900mL of heptane. Next, a heptane solution of TiBA (2.40mmol) and a toluene solution of Azu-Zr (600μmol) were successively introduced into the flask. The mixture was stirred for 1h at room temperature. Next, the total volume of the resulting dispersion of the catalyst was adjusted to 500mL by adding heptane, and the dispersion was transferred to a 1L autoclave with a mechanical stirrer and a temperature controller. Prepolymerization was performed by feeding propylene continuously (at a constant rate of 10g/h) into the autoclave for 4h at 40°C. After the propylene feed was stopped, the reaction was allowed to continue for 1h. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 1L flask, and the liquid phase was removed by the cannula technique. Next, the heptane solution of TiBA (12mmol) was added to the dense slurry as a scavenger for the catalyst poisons under mechanical agitation. Finally, the mixture was dried by vacuum evaporation at 40°C, yielding the prepolymerized catalyst (KF(7)). 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 Chemical composition The Al, Si, Mg, Fe, and Na contents of MMT were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) (Rigaku ZNX-100e) using the calibration method. 2.3.2 Measurement of amounts of acid by titration The amounts of acid in the original and chemically treated MMT samples were measured by titration using an automated titration system (GT100, Mitsubishi Chemical Analytech Co., Ltd.) in combination with a photonic multichannel analyzer (PMA-11, Hamamatsu Photonics K.K.). The samples (150–250mg) were suspended in dry toluene (5mL) and transferred to the test cell. An excess Hammett indicator (anthraquinone for pKa<−8.2, 2-benzalacetophenone for pKa<−5.6) was added to the sample suspension. Titration was performed under the following conditions: Titer: toluene solution of 2,6-dimethylpyridine Titration rate: 0.02mL/min (drop wise) UV measurements: interval=5min, wavelength=250–800nm The decrease in the acidic form of the Hammett indicator because of the addition of the basic titer was monitored using the UV spectrometer. The cumulative volume of the added titer was recorded as the end point of titration, when a further decrease in the concentration could no longer be observed. 2.3.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The distances between adjacent MMT layers for KF, KF(2), KF(4), KF(5), KF(6), and KF(7) were determined through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses. The measurements were performed under the following conditions: Instrument: Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (SmartLab); X-ray source: Cu-Kα, operated at 40kV and 30mA (Ni filter was used); slit: divergence slit 2/3°, scattering slit 2/3°, and receiving slit 0.3mm; detector scan speed and resolution: 4.0°/min and 0.02°; sample preparation: Kunipia F was dried in vacuo at 200°C for 2h. The other samples were used without any treatment. During the XRD measurements, all the samples were kept in a N2 atmosphere using an airproof sample cell (manufactured by Rigaku) with a Kapton window. The background signal of the empty cell was subtracted from the raw data. 2.3.4 Electron microscopy analysis instrument A field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM) system (JEOL Ltd., JEM2100F, 200kV FE) equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (JEOL Ltd., JED2300) and an energy-filter spectrometer (GATAN Inc., GIF Quantum system) was used for analysis. 2.3.4.1 Grid preparation Three types of grids, namely a carbon-film-coated copper grid, a holey carbon film-coated copper grid (conventional microgrid), and a copper grid coated with a plasma-polymerized naphthalene film, were used for supporting the sample particles after the samples had been subjected to a hydrophilic treatment using an ion-sputtering device (JEOL Ltd., JFC1100). The hydrophilic treatment was carried out under the following conditions: 0.5kV, 10mA, 10s. 2.3.4.2 STEM-EDS An energy-dispersive spectrometry (STEM-EDS) system was used to quantitatively analyze the Al/Si molar ratio of the MMT sample. The value detected by the STEM-EDS measurement was calibrated as follows; three clay mineral samples were used as the standard materials, for which the Al/Si molar ratios, as determined by XRF, were 0.17, 0.33, and 0.41, respectively. For the STEM-EDS measurement of the standard sample, the sample was dispersed in distilled water, and the concentration was adjusted to 0.05wt%. Then, 5μL of the suspension was dropped onto the carbon-film-coated copper grid and dried at 60°C for 1h. The X-ray intensities of Al and Si were recorded. The EDS spectrum was obtained under the following conditions: STEM mode, magnification of 60,000×, spot size of 1.5nm, scanning area of 2μm×2μm, and counting time of 180s. Based on the correlation between the XRF data (Al/Si molar ratios) and STEM-EDS data (Al/Si intensity count ratios), the following relationship was obtained. STEM-EDS (Al/Si count ratio)=1.027×XRF (Al/Si molar ratio) Next, KF(2) was analyzed by STEM-EDS. The sample preparation and spectrum recording conditions, except the scanning area (changed to 200nm×200nm), were the same as those described above. The EDS spectrum corresponding to a selected region in the obtained STEM image was reanalyzed to determine the elemental composition. 2.3.4.3 EFTEM KF(2) was dispersed in distilled water, and the concentration was adjusted to 0.05wt%. Then, 5μL of the suspension was dropped onto the microgrid and dried at 60°C for 1h. An energy-filter TEM (EFTEM) system with a Gatan imaging filter was used for the carbon mapping of the sample, which was done under the following conditions: three-window method, CK pre-edge-1 of 252eV, CK pre-edge-2 of 272eV, CK post-edge of 294eV, energy gap of 20eV, and exposure time of 60s. 2.3.4.4 TEM TEM images of KF and KF(6) were obtained using the simple TEM mode. A higher tilt holder was used. The sample to be imaged was fixed on the copper grid coated with the plasma-polymerized naphthalene film using the procedure employed for the EFTEM analysis. 3 Results and discussion The typical procedure for synthesizing MMT-supported metallocene catalysts for propylene polymerization consists of four steps, as shown in Scheme 1 . First, the raw material, MMT, is treated with an acid (usually H2SO4), because MMT does not contain strong acid sites. The crude product is washed with water and dried under vacuum, in order to remove the undesirable water of constitution. Next, the acid-treated MMT is treated with alkyl aluminum (AA) and washed, as it contains a number of reactive hydroxide groups on its surface. Then, a metallocene is supported on the AA-treated MMT obtained in the second step. The reaction product is a catalyst capable of polymerizing α-olefins. Usually, the obtained catalyst is made to come in contact with a small amount of propylene, in order to stabilize it through the production of polypropylene. This step is called prepolymerization. On the basis of the above procedure, we investigated the chemical and structural changes induced in MMT in a step-by-step manner. 3.1 Chemical changes in MMT after acid treatment From the viewpoint of the chemical changes induced in MMT during the preparation procedure shown in Scheme 1, the acid treatment is the most important step, because it dramatically changes the chemical composition and acidity of MMT. Treatment with an acid is a popular method of producing acid sites on the surfaces of clay minerals and involves the leaching of a few metal ions [22–24]. We selected Kunipia F as a typical MMT in this study and investigated the effects of the reaction time of the acid treatment on the properties of the obtained acid-treated MMT sample, as described in the Section 2. The chemical composition and acidity were analyzed using XRF and the Hammett titration method, respectively. The obtained results are listed in Table 1 . Al atoms leached gradually with an increase in the reaction time; this was accompanied by the formation of acid sites. Even though KF did not have any acid sites, approximately 10% leaching in the case of KF(1) was enough to form a few acid sites, including stronger ones (pKa<−8.2). Indeed, the concentration of the acid sites increased as the leaching process progressed (that is, for KF(2) and KF(3)). However, the proportion of stronger sites remained the same, roughly 25%. Therefore, the microscopic structures around the acid sites probably did not depend on the total degree of leaching, at least from the viewpoint of the acidity distribution. In other words, the characteristics of the individual acid sites might depend not on the total or averaged characteristics of MMT but on the local ones. We then explored analysis of the chemical composition distributions in acid-treated MMT. Since a leaching of Al atom is the key for formation of the acid site, the elemental mapping in MMT should provide certain evidence concerning location of the acid site. STEM-EDS was employed to analyzed the KF(2) sample, as a selected example of acid treated MMT, to investigate the local composition, especially Al and Si contents. Due to their stacked layer structure of clay minerals, we tried to peel the layers as much as possible by suspension in a very dilute slurry of the clay sample for the purpose. Fig. 2 shows a STEM image of the platelets of KF(2). We selected a few analysis points in Fig. 2 and performed EDS analyses at these points over a scanning area of 200nm×200nm. The obtained compositional information is given in Table 2 . The Si atom intensity is shown as the detected count number. The estimated leaching degree, (Al0-Al)/Al0, which was determined based on the correlation between Al/Si and (Al0-Al)/Al0, is also listed in Table 1. Since the Si count numbers of the 6 selected points was almost constant at approximately 2000 and since Si did not get leached by the acid treatment, the selected points were considered as having clay mineral layers of equivalent thicknesses (numbers of layers). Based on this hypothesis, we assumed that the impact of the thickness on the signal intensity had been compensated for and that the composition of each point could be compared. For measured point #6, which was the center of a clay mineral platelet, the Al cation extraction value was negative. However, it was very close to zero, which implied that Al leaching at the center of the clay platelet might not have taken place at all. On the other hand, (Al0-Al)/Al0 clearly increased as one moved towards the border of the platelet. Therefore, it can be concluded that the acid sites were located mainly on the border. 3.2 Investigation of active site location in the MMT-supported metallocene catalyst system As described above, only the border part of each layer was chemically modified and deformed by the acid treatment of MMT. Therefore, the formed strong acid sites and the metallocene molecules activated by them would be located on the sample surface and not the interlayers. This hypothesis is opposite to that suggested by Kurokawa, who, based on an XRD analysis, stated that ethylene is polymerized by intercalated active metallocene molecules, once the individual layers in the metallocene catalyst system supported on Mg2+-treated mica had been peeled. Hence, we performed a similar XRD analysis as well as EFTEM observations on the various samples prepared by bringing the acid-treated MMT sample in contact with various chemical compounds for polymerization and compared the results with those for Kurokawa’s catalyst system. 3.2.1 XRD analysis to evaluate interlayer distance of various MMT samples The interlayer distances (d-spacings) of the various MMT samples were investigated by XRD analyses. The samples were prepared as described in the Section 2, while taking into account the general procedure for synthesizing MMT-supported metallocene catalysts, and, in particular, the amounts of chemical compounds used. The (001) diffraction peak of MMT was observed at 2θ of 3–10°. The spacing of the (001) layers (i.e., the d-spacing) were calculated from the peak angle using Eq. (1). (1) d = λ 2 sin θ where λ is the wavelength (1.541Å). The obtained results are shown in Table 3 and Fig. 3 . The untreated MMT sample, namely, KF, showed a diffraction pattern similar to that of smectite. Further, its d-spacing was 0.97nm and equal to the value published for dehydrated MMT [25,26]. The general procedure for synthesizing MMT-supported metallocene catalyst consists of three chemical treatment steps, namely, successive treatments with sulfuric acid, TiBA, and the metallocene complex. The samples corresponding to these steps (KF(2), KF(4), and KF(5), respectively) exhibited the same d-spacing as the raw material KF. Similarly, polymerization did not influence the d-spacing (KF(6) and KF(7)). Consequently, no component of the MMT-supported catalyst system was intercalated into the layers, at least not when used in amounts typical for catalyst preparation. Thus, it was concluded that the active sites must be located on the surfaces of the MMT particles (and not the interlayer), because polymerization did not change the d-spacing. This difference between Kurokawa’s catalyst [18] and those prepared in this study strongly suggested that a detailed study of the reaction mechanism is necessary for fully understanding and exploiting the potential of clay minerals as catalysts for olefin polymerization. 3.2.2 TEM analysis of catalyst sample containing tiny amount of polypropylene The investigation described in the section titled “Chemical changes in MMT after acid treatment” revealed that only the borders of the platelets were physically and chemically changed by the acid treatment of MMT. In addition, the XRD analysis described in the section “Investigation of active site location in the MMT-supported metallocene catalyst system” suggested that only the complexes on the surfaces of the clay mineral crystals were activated in the case of propylene polymerization using the metallocene catalyst supported on the acid-treated MMT. Next, we performed a TEM analysis in order to determine the location of a small amount of polypropylene on the surface of KF(6), which was prepared by nascent polymerization using the metallocene catalyst supported on the acid-treated MMT, KF(2). If polymerization is quenched just after the start of the process, the catalyst particles will contain a very small amount of polypropylene, and it should be possible to identify the location of the polymerization sites. Fig. 4 shows TEM images of KF(2) and KF(6). As shown in Fig. 4a, KF(2), the acid-treated MMT sample, consisted of platelets whose average size was approximately 1000nm. Most of these platelets were 200–2000nm in size. On the other hand, KF(6) consisted of globular particles whose size was approximately 20nm, in addition to the larger platelets of MMT, as shown in Fig. 4b. These smaller globular particles were not dispersed uniformly on the surfaces of the MMT platelets but were aligned and connected to each other, forming a fiber-like structure that was very similar to the “fibril” substructure of polypropylene [27]. In the wide-view image in Fig. 4c and the high-tilted image in Fig. 4d, these globular particles (darker particles) are located on the edges of the MMT platelets. Next, we performed an EFTEM analysis, in order to confirm that these globular particles were of polypropylene (Fig. 5 ) [28]. Fig. 5a is a zero-loss image of KF(6). A fiber-like structure comprising globular particles and similar to that observed in Fig. 4b can be seen. The corresponding carbon map is shown in Fig. 5b; the brighter parts are rich in carbon. Further, there is a good correlation between the location of the globular particles in Fig. 5a and the brighter parts in Fig. 5b. Thus, it was concluded that the globular particles were of polypropylene, because there was no other carbon-rich material in the system. Therefore, Fig. 4b–d confirmed that the produced polypropylene was located on the edges of the MMT platelets. Taking into account the fact that the polymerization process was quenched quickly after being started, it was concluded the produced polypropylene was located near the polymerization sites. Consequently, the metallocene complex was activated only on the borders of the acid-treated MMT platelets. 4 Conclusions The location of the active sites of a propylene polymerization catalyst comprising chemically treated MMT and a metallocene complex was investigated by analyzing the chemical and structural changes induced in MMT during the synthesis steps and the polymerization process. This was done with the aim of improving our understanding of the catalyst system. The chemical changes induced by the acid treatment of MMT were investigated by XRF, the Hammett titration method, and STEM-EDS. It was found that the gradual leaching of Al atoms from the borders of the MMT platelets to their centers was accompanied by acid site formation. Therefore, the acid sites are mainly located on the borders. The structural changes induced by the chemical treatment of MMT during the catalyst synthesis steps and the polymerization process were investigated using XRD and TEM. Because the interlayer distance (d-spacing) was not influenced by any of the treatments, no component of the MMT-supported metallocene catalyst system was intercalated into the layers under the typical synthesis conditions. In addition, polypropylene production was only observed on the edges of the MMT platelets. Consequently, the metallocene complex was activated only on the borders of the acid-treated MMT particles. To conclude, we clarified the location of the active sites of an MMT-supported metallocene catalyst. If one takes into account the fact that the acid sites on clay minerals are indispensable for metallocene activation, as described in the introduction, the most plausible mechanism to describe the observed phenomenon is that the metallocene complex is activated by the acid sites formed on the borders of the platelets by the acid treatment of the clay mineral, as shown in Scheme 2 . coredata.dc:description: In this study, we investigated the location of the active sites of montmorillonite-supported metallocene catalysts used for propylene polymerization. X-ray fluorescence, Hammett titration, and scanning transmission electron microscopy/energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy revealed that the gradual leaching of Al atoms from the borders of the platelets to their centers and acid site formation occurred when montmorillonite was subjected to an acid treatment. X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy analyses indicated that the metallocene complex was activated only on the borders of the acid-treated montmorillonite platelets. The most plausible explanation for this phenomenon is that the metallocene complex is activated by the acid sites formed on the borders of the platelets by the acid treatment of montmorillonite.
